results.title: The Decision
results.creator_credit: Vera Neubauer and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: An experimental film using a mixture of animation and live action which contrasts the fantasy and romantic ideals of the traditional fairy tale with the life of an ordinary woman confined to her home.

results.title: The Seventh mandarin
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Xerox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Desire to read”.
Long ago in a walled palace lived a Chiense emperor, guarded and guided by seven assistants called mandarins. None of them ever set foot outside the palace and they knew nothing of the people until the seventh and youngest mandarin ventured out one night…Based on the picture book by Jane Yolen.

results.title: The World's greatest freak show
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Xerox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Desire to read”.
A cartoon adventure designed to develop reading skills by visualising book materials. Presents the story of a man who in his efforts to obtain riches, exploits freaks for theatrical purposes. Based on the picture book by Ellen Raskin. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: The Descent
results.creator_credit: Andrew Schultz, David Atkinson, John Bird, Film Victoria and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A claymation (influenced by Jan Svankmejer in sepia tones and use of stop-still animated found objects and cut-tin figurines) depicts a storm ravaged landscape of an empire. The ruling giant, ‘metal’ Queen summons her miniature servants to find and rescue her giant clay King. Like ants the small servants work together to unite the King and Queen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Schultz, David Atkinson, John Bird, Film Victoria and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: The Day off
results.creator_credit: Sidney Goldsmith, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A day off allows us from routine existence, but it also prepares us for re-entering the workday world. In this animated film people relaxing on a beach are constantly being reminded of tragic events happening elsewhere. By the end of the day they are able to return to the real world and continue to ‘function’. (Awards: Melbourne)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sidney Goldsmith, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Delights of Turkey
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Greg Grainger journeys for 4,000 km around Western Turkey on a motorcycle. Beginning in Istanbul, home of the more liberal Turkish Muslims, we visit famous tourist venues such as the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia and the magnificent Grant Bazaar. Travelling along the coast, we see the increasing numbers of young Australians making their pilgrimage to Gallipoli at Anzac Cove. Remains of Roman civilization and architecture are evident throughout Western Turkey and Greg’s group rides in a hot air balloon over the strange cave houses of Cappadocia. Traditional farming and carpet making in rural areas are shown as happily co-existing with the more modern tourist attractions of restaurants, belly dancing and shopping in the cities.

results.title: The Decline of Tsarism
results.creator_credit: Ian Thompson and University of Warwick
results.brief_description: Using archival footage, this program studies the military defeats and growing social unrest that resulted in the 1917 abdication of Tzar Nicholas II, ending the Romanov dynasty in Russia.
results.description: Using archival footage, this program studies the military defeats and growing social unrest that resulted in the 1917 abdication of Tzar Nicholas II, ending the Romanov dynasty in Russia.

results.title: The Dead heart [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, ABC-TV (Australia), BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, 35 years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode two explores Australia’s national pride and nostalgia with the outback - despite the fact that only 1% of the population actually live there. Hughes traces the myths borne out of the bush that have dominated our history and folklore - especially in art - covering icons such as the shearer, the swagman, the explorer and the lost child. He also visits a sheep-shearing station, an Aboriginal community in the Kimberleys, Port Arthur historical site, an opal mine in Coober Pedy, forest in Tasmania and Ayers Rock. Native title and the myth of an infinitely rich and exploitable landscape are also discussed.
